body:
Unfortunately, ADTK is not permissive open source, so we can't make it a dependency.
I'm also not sure how well it is supported still.

Though, if you want outlier detection, I suggest `pyod`:
https://github.com/yzhao062/pyod

So, we could wrap the `pyod` interface (for i.i.d./tabular data) for use with temporal scenarios via reduction?
This looks to be a good one, it has got some techniques specific for time series - https://github.com/SeldonIO/alibi-detect

yes, indeed! Thanks for making us aware of this. @mloning FYI, also good to have on the related work page?

They do not seem to have a pipeline structure though - so it might be a good idea to construct:
* a seldon interface, with a cleaner API design for scitype handling (e.g., time series input or tabular input? annotators and detectors)
* some functionality similar to sklearn `Pipeline` or ADTK `PipeNet`; on that note, I believe @viktorkaz wanted to build something similar to that

#### Reference Issues/PRs

you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
Added alibi-detect to docs/source/related_software.rst as per #798  .
#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

No

body: For the last several weeks I've been working on a design of a pipeline which can also be used for outlier detection. You can find the preliminary code [here](https://github.com/ViktorKaz/sktime/tree/pipeline/sktime/pipeline). This is related to Issue https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/763.

so... how do we proceed with this?
There are multiple non-exclusive options I can see:
* interface to `pyod`
* interface to `alibi-detect`
* extend @ViktorKaz's pipeline design to cover generic temporal on-line anomaly detection
I am already on it. I am developing the interface to PyOD, I had a call with @mloning  to get the design sketch(which I will update as an enhancement proposal ).

issue.title: Pipeline for Online Directional Forecasts

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
# Problem

In financial applications it is common to be interested in predicting at time $t$ the direction of change for an asset at time $t+m$, where $m \geq 1$ is a future time period. Generally speaking, there are three possibilities. In the time period $[t,t+m]$ either the price can go up, down or there will be no change. 

This problem can be decomposed in several smaller, more manageable ones, namely:

1. Dimensionality Reduction and/or Feature Extraction
1. Feature Transformation
1. Changepoint Detection
1. Annotation (Labelling)
1. Temporal cross validation and estimator tuning

 
# Solution
Ideally, we would have a pipeline which chains together the different elements of the algorithm. In contrast to `sklearn` pipelines we will need the capability to chain the different steps in the pipeline not only sequentially but in any giver order. Furthermore, we will need a functionality for transforming and processing both the features and the labels in our dataset.

# Alternatives
`mlfinlab` has functionality with which directional forecasts can be made. However, it is not implemented as a pipeline but rather as a collection of loose functions organised in modules. Furthermore, `mlfinlab` is not open source. 

Other open source toolboxes that tackle at least part of the problem include:
* `ruptures` deals with change point detection, 
* `ADTK` with anomaly detection (specific case of change point detection), 
* `PyOD` was covers outlier detection (specific case of change point detection)

# Additional context

## Background: `mlfinab` example

```Python
#feature reduction and annotation
daily_vol = ml.util.volatility.get_daily_vol(close=dollar_bars['close'], lookback=5)
cusum_events = ml.filters.cusum_filter(dollar_bars['close'], threshold=-0.1)
vertical_barriers = ml.labeling.add_vertical_barrier(t_events=cusum_events, close=dollar_bars['close'], num_days=5)
triple_barrier_events = ml.labeling.get_events(close=dollar_bars['close'],
                                                t_events=cusum_events,
                                                pt_sl=[1, 1], # sets the width of the barriers
                                                target=daily_vol * 2, # twice the daily vol
                                                min_ret=0.005,
                                                num_threads=4,
                                                vertical_barrier_times=vertical_barriers,
                                                side_prediction=None,
                                                verbose=False)
triple_labels = ml.labeling.get_bins(triple_barrier_events, dollar_bars['close'])

#tune and fit an estimator
train_idx, test_idx = train_test_split(np.arange(dataset.shape[0]), shuffle=False, test_size=0.25)
cv_gen = ml.cross_validation.PurgedKFold(samples_info_sets=samples_info_sets['t1'].iloc[train_idx], n_splits=5, pct_embargo=0.01)
gs = GridSearchCV(estimator=estimator, param_grid=param_grid, scoring='neg_log_loss', cv=cv_gen)
train_dts = dataset.iloc[train_idx]
X = train_dts.iloc[:,0:lookback]
y = train_dts['bin']

gs.fit(X,y)
```



## Background: `sktime` transformers

Below is the `sktime` base transformer class
```Python

class BaseTransformer(BaseEstimator):
    """Transformer base class"""

    def __init__(self):
        super(BaseTransformer, self).__init__()

    def fit(self, Z, X=None):
        """
        Fit transformer to X and y.
        By default, fit is empty. Fittable transformations overwrite fit method.
        Parameters
        ----------
        Z : TimeSeries
            Data to be transformed
        X : TimeSeries, optional (default=None)
            Extra data
        Returns
        -------
        self : a fitted instance of the estimator
        """
        self._is_fitted = True
        return self

    def transform(self, Z, X=None):
        """Transform data. Returns a transformed version of X."""
        raise NotImplementedError("abstract method")

    def fit_transform(self, Z, X=None):
        """Fit to data, then transform it.
        Fits transformer to X and y with optional parameters fit_params
        and returns a transformed version of X.
        Parameters
        ----------
        Z : pd.DataFrame, pd.Series or np.ndarray
            Data to be transformed
        X : pd.Series or np.ndarray, optional (default=None)
            Target values of data to be transformed.
        Returns
        -------
        Zt : pd.DataFrame, pd.Series or np.ndarray
            Transformed data.
        """
        # Non-optimized default implementation; override when a better
        # method is possible for a given algorithm.
        if X is None:
            # Fit method of arity 1 (unsupervised transformation)
            return self.fit(Z).transform(Z)
        else:
            # Fit method of arity 2 (supervised transformation)
            return self.fit(Z, X).transform(Z)
```

Private transformer classes inherit from base transformer. The defining characteristic of the transformers are their input and output types.

```Python
class _SeriesToPrimitivesTransformer(BaseTransformer):
    """Transformer base class for series to primitive(s) transforms"""

    def transform(self, Z: Series, X=None) -> Primitives:
        raise NotImplementedError("abstract method")


class _SeriesToSeriesTransformer(BaseTransformer):
    """Transformer base class for series to series transforms"""

    def transform(self, Z: Series, X=None) -> Series:
        raise NotImplementedError("abstract method")


class _PanelToTabularTransformer(BaseTransformer):
    """Transformer base class for panel to tabular transforms"""

    def transform(self, X: Panel, y=None) -> Tabular:
        raise NotImplementedError("abstract method")


class _PanelToPanelTransformer(BaseTransformer):
    """Transformer base class for panel to panel transforms"""

    def transform(self, X: Panel, y=None) -> Panel:
        raise NotImplementedError("abstract method")
```

## Pipeline: proposed user journey


```Python
pipeline = OnlineUnsupervisedPipeline(
    [
        ('feature_extraction', DollarBars(price_col ='Price', volume_col ='Volume'), input_values={'X':'original_series'} ), # input_values={'X':'original_series'} can be omitted
        ('changepoint_detection',CUSUM(), input_values={'X':'feature_extraction'}),
        ('labeling', TripleBarrier(price_col='closing_price'), input_values={ 'change_points':'changepoint_detection', 'prices':'feature_extraction'}), 
        ('build_dataset', DatasetBuilder(lookback=20), input_values={ 'untransformed_series':'original_series','changepoint_detection':'changepoint_detection'}), 
        ('estimator',SVC(), input_values={'X':'build_dataset','y':'labelling'})
    ]
)
pipeline.fit(X)

```

## Scientific Types and Templates

The pipeline is comprised of different steps. We propose that each of the algorithms comprising the pipeline is a `transformer`, except the last one which will be an `estimator`.

The scientific type of the transformers will be defined by reference to the input and output types that the transformer handles. The existing `sktime` templates will be used and new ones will be added.

```Python
class __ComplexToTabularTransformer(BaseTransformer):
	"""
	New transformer abstract base class that takes as inputs two or more different types 
	"""
	def transform (self, inputs) -> Tabular:
		pass
class DollarBars(_PanelToTabularTransformer):
	"""
	The input will need to be to the fit method is a Pandas Dataframe with arbitrry names of the columns. We need to specify the names of the columns that the algorithm will be looking for.
	
	Parameters
	----------
	price_col : string
	volume_col : sting
	threashold : float
		aggregation threashold
	return_col_names : array
		array with names of columns in the transformed pandas dataframe
	"""
	def __init__(self, price_col, volume_col, threashold, return_col_names=['high_price','low_price','open_price','close_price','num_trades','cumul_dollar_value']):
		pass
		
	
	def fit(self, X):
		"""
		Finds the cut off agregation points in the input dataset X
		
		Paramters
		---------
		X : Pandas DataFrame
			columns: index - timestamps, Price, Volume, etc
		"""
		
		pass
		
		
	def transform(self):
		"""
		Returns Aggregated X
		
		Returns
		-------
			Pandas DataFrame, where index - timestamp, columns - high price, low price, open, close, number of trades cumulative dollar value, etc
		"""
	def fit_transfom(self, X):
		"""
		calls the fit and the transofmr methods sequentially
		"""
		pass
	def update(self,X):
		"""
		Performs update only for the new values since the last run of fit_transform and concatenates the results to the DataFrame previously returned by the `transform` method.
		"""
		pass
		
class CUSUM(_SeriesToSeriesTransformer):
	"""
	 CUSUM is q quality control method designed to detect a shift in the mean value of a measured quantity away from a target value.
	Parameters
	----------
	target_col:string
		name of input column
	threashold : float
		defines shift from target value		
	"""
	def __init__(self,target_col, threashold):
		pass
	def fit(self, X):
		"""
		Paramters
		---------
		X : Pandas Dataframe or Pandas Series
			columns index-timestamps, closing price
		"""
		pass
	def transform(self):
		"""
		Returns
		-------
			array : index values from the input dataset that represent change points
		"""
		pass
	def fit_transfom(self, X):
		"""
		calls the fit and the transofmr methods sequentially
		"""
		pass
	def update(self,X):
		"""
		Performs update only for the new values since the last run of fit_transform and concatenates the results to the DataFrame previously returned by the `transform` method.
		"""
		pass
class TrippleBarrier(_ComplexToTabularTransformer):
	def __init__(self, price_col):
		"""
		Parameters
		----------
		price_col : string
			name of column in prices pandas DataFrame used as parameter to the `fit` method
		"""
	def fit(self, prices, change_points):
		"""
		Finds indexes where the barrier is touched, calculates labels
		
		Parameters
		----------
		prices: Pandas DataFrame
			dataset with aggregated prices
		change_points: array
			array of indices with change points
			
		"""
		pass
	def transform(self):
		"""
		Returns calculated values
		
		Returns
		-------
			Pandas Dataframe with the following columns: 
				index : timestamps same as returned by the change point detection algorithm
				col1 : index of event when the barrier was touched
				col2 : label (upper barrier touched, lower barrier touched, time expired without touching barrier)		
		"""
		pass

	def fit_transfom(self, X):
		"""
		calls the fit and the transofmr methods sequentially
		"""
		pass
	def update(self,prices, change_points):
		"""
		Performs update only for the new values since the last run of fit_transform and concatenates the results to the DataFrame previously returned by the `transform` method.
		"""
		pass
class DatasetBuilder(_ComplexToTabularTransformer):
	"""
	Builds the dataset in the correct format that can be used by the estimator at the end of the pipeline, e.g. tabular, time series, etc.
	
	
	Parameters
	---------
	lookback : int
		Lookback in number of periods counting from each changepoint event
	"""
	def __init__(self, lookback):
		pass
	
	def fit(self,x_input,y_input):
		"""
		x_input: dictionary
			dictionary with values from which the Dataset Builder will be able to compile the features of the dataset
		y_input : dictionary
			dictionary with values from which the Dataset Builder will be able to compile the labels of the dataset
		"""
		pass
	def transform(self):
		"""
		Returns the result of `fit`
		"""
	def fit_transform(self):
		"""
		Calls sequentially fit and transform
		"""
		pass
	def update(self, x_input, y_input):
		"""
		Updates the dataset with the new values since last run
		"""
		pass

class OnlineUnsupervisedPipeline(BaseEstimator):
	"""
	The pipeline will act as a `glue` between the steps.
	
	Main requirements
	1. Check steps for consistency
	2. Create dictionary with  parameters from inputs. Instantiate steps, call functions using synthax step_func(**created_dict), where the keys of created_dict correspond to step_func arguments.
	"""
	def fit(self, X):
		pass
	def predict(self):
		pass
	def fit_predict(X):
		pass
	def update(X):
		pass
```

<!--
Thanks for contributing a pull request! Please ensure you have taken a look
at our contribution guide: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md
-->

#### Reference Issues/PRs
<!--
Example: Fixes #1234. See also #3456.

Please use keywords (e.g., Fixes) to create link to the issues or pull requests
you resolved, so that they will automatically be closed when your pull request
is merged. See https://github.com/blog/1506-closing-issues-via-pull-requests
-->
With regards to #798 

#### What does this implement/fix? Explain your changes.
<!--
A clear and concise description of what you have implemented.
-->
Creates a Base Class for Annotations.
#### Does your contribution introduce a new dependency? If yes, which one?

<!--
If your contribution does add a new hard dependency, we may suggest to initially develop your contribution in a separate companion package in https://github.com/sktime/ to keep external dependencies of the core sktime package to a minimum.
-->

#### What should a reviewer concentrate their feedback on?

<!-- This section is particularly useful if you have a pull request that is still in development. You can guide the reviews to focus on the parts that are ready for their comments. We suggest using bullets (indicated by * or -) and filled checkboxes [x] here -->
If the Base Estimator contains the proper code and is in the proper directory.
#### Any other comments?
<!--
Please be aware that we are a loose team of volunteers so patience is necessary; assistance handling other issues is very welcome. We value all user contributions, no matter how minor they are. If we are slow to review, either the pull request needs some benchmarking, tinkering, convincing, etc. or more likely the reviewers are simply busy. In either case, we ask for your understanding during the review process.
-->

#### PR checklist
<!--
Please go through the checklist below. Please feel free to remove points if they are not applicable.
-->

##### For all contributions
- [ ] I've added myself to the [list of contributors](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/.all-contributorsrc).
- [ ] Optionally, I've updated sktime's [CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/blob/main/CODEOWNERS) to receive notifications about future changes to these files.
- [ ] I've added unit tests and made sure they pass locally.

##### For new estimators
- [ ] I've added the estimator to the online documentation.
- [ ] I've updated the existing example notebooks or provided a new one to showcase how my estimator works.


<!--
Thanks for contributing!
-->
